5926.txt.context_sentence: With its own special beer for the lighting ceremony, too.
5926.txt.next_sentence_true: The Genesee Brewery Keg Tree will be lit Friday, Dec. 7 near the Genesee Brew House overlooking Rochester's High Falls.
5926.txt.full: ROCHESTER, NY -- It only started 5 years ago, but already it's one of Upstate New York's most treasured holiday traditions. After all, where else are you going to find a 27-foot tall tree made entirely of empty beer kegs? With its own special beer for the lighting ceremony, too. The Genesee Brewery Keg Tree will be lit Friday, Dec. 7 near the Genesee Brew House overlooking Rochester's High Falls. It's a bit bigger and brighter than in past years, with 525 empty kegs and 20,000 lights. The party is 6 to 9 p.m next the brew house at 25 Cataract St., off St. Paul Street, near the big Genesee Brewery.  The lighting itself is at 7 p.m. The brewery expects -- and is prepared for -- thousands of onlookers. "Our keg tree has become somewhat of a holiday landmark in Rochester, so we know that people are going to come in masses on December 7 to see it lit," said Mike Gaesser, Genesee's "Keg Tree Creator." The lighting ceremony includes live music and food and beer trucks. There's also the release of Keg Tree Ale, a version of the brewery's famed cream ale made with cinnamon.  Keg Tree Ale will debut Dec. 7 at the Genesee Brew House, the pilot brewery and taproom adjacent to the big Genny brewery. It will be available on draft and in growlers and crowlers until supplies run out. This year, the lighting ceremony also features special hand-made holiday wreaths.  With each wreath purchased, one will be donated to the community. KEG TREE LIGHTING EVENT WHAT: Genesee Brewery's Keg Tree lighting holiday party. No cost for entry. WHEN: 6-9 p.m. Friday, Dec. 7. Lighting at 7 p.m. WHERE: Genesee Brew House, 25 Cataract Street, Rochester, NY 14605

6039.txt.full: Before anything else, 89-year-old Jimmy Carter said "Roll Tide," after the University of Alabama beat University of Georgia for the SEC Championship title earlier on Saturday. Blind Boys of Alabama, a gospel group that's been continuously active since the original members met at the Alabama Institute for the Negro Blind in 1939, stopped by the Homer Center for the Arts as part of their annual Christmas Tour. They blended in Christmas classics with their time-tested discography of originals and blues-infused covers. Their Southern sounds permeated the renovated Baptist church. Their age brought a certain kind of wisdom that only elderly people bring. "We're hoping we can say something that can lift you up," Carter said. "We want you to know that we love you." The five-time Grammy winners had four chairs lined up on stage, for them to sit in when they needed to. Their security guard led them on and off stage single-file as they put a hand on the shoulder in front of them - they are blind, after all. They played some of their signature songs, including a cover of "Spirit in the Sky" by Norman Greenbaum. Originally a Vietnam War-era rock song with gospel influences. The Blind Boys' version was a gospel song with Vietnam War era influences. Singer Ben Moore's microphone stopped working and bassist Trae Pierce helped him fix it. Vocalist Paul Beasley had many shining moments that night, but one of them was during "Merry Christmas To You," when he first demonstrated how high his voice could go, holding his fist high in the air.

They played some of their signature songs, including a cover of "Spirit in the Sky" by Norman Greenbaum. Originally a Vietnam War-era rock song with gospel influences. The Blind Boys' version was a gospel song with Vietnam War era influences. Singer Ben Moore's microphone stopped working and bassist Trae Pierce helped him fix it. Vocalist Paul Beasley had many shining moments that night, but one of them was during "Merry Christmas To You," when he first demonstrated how high his voice could go, holding his fist high in the air. He also screeched those high notes of "There Will Never Be Any Peace," singing "we need peace" and inviting the audience to join him for the word "peace." The Blind Boys twisted their Southern influence into plenty of favorite Christmas tunes, including "White Christmas," "Silent Night," and their version of "Go Tell it on the Mountain" that won them a Grammy in 2004. For the record, "Go Tell it on the Mountain" makes so much sense as a blues song. Another of their unexpected blues covers came with "Amazing Grace," where they modified the melody to follow the chords and vocal structure of "House of the Rising Sun." Jimmy Carter held an extremely long note - so long that he had to sit down and stand back up again before it was finished. Sings of their age and handicap did occasionally pop up. As Paul Beasley stood and wailed away on his high notes, Pierce held his chair steady for him so he wouldn't knock it over or fall down. The four blind vocalists could not see that their entire audience was standing as they played one of their songs. They could hear them clapping in time with it, though. The last song of the night was an 8-minute long jam to "Pray for Peace," which kept jamming as security led Carter for a slow walk around the whole auditorium, so he could say thank you to his fans, shake their hands, and give out hugs.
6044.txt.next_sentence_generated: The audience finished singing it for him and also to their favorite tunes including a covers version on Green Mountain Boys Tour 2004

6049.txt.context_sentence: The only new wide release of the weekend was the Sony Pictures R-rated horror feature The Possession of Hannah Grace, which landed in seventh place after collecting $6.5 million.
6049.txt.next_sentence_true: The movie cost $9.5 million before marketing costs, according to Box Office Mojo.
6049.txt.full: Walt Disney Co.'s Ralph Breaks the Internet dominated U.S. theaters for a second weekend, rising above a typically quiet post-Thanksgiving slate. The animated sequel to Wreck-it-Ralph generated $25.8 million, according to box office estimates Sunday. That was shy of the $28 million estimated by Box Office Pro analysts. The movie still has a ways to go before it will make back its budget. Ralph Breaks the Internet cost $175 million to produce -- before marketing costs -- according to Box Office Mojo. The movie opened in the U.K. this weekend and will continue its global rollout later this month and into next year. The only new wide release of the weekend was the Sony Pictures R-rated horror feature The Possession of Hannah Grace, which landed in seventh place after collecting $6.5 million. The movie cost $9.5 million before marketing costs, according to Box Office Mojo. It beat a forecast of $3.2 million by Box Office Pro.

6075.txt.context_sentence: Neals, a critically acclaimed singer, is also a notable pianist, arranger, and bandleader.
6075.txt.next_sentence_true: Throughout a celebrated career, Neals' most recent award was "Blues Artist of the Year" at the 2018 Detroit Black Music Awards.
6075.txt.full: Get ready for a fun week of shows. From indie pop to soulful blues, stages in Central New York will be buzzing with the sights and sounds of a good time Rubblebucket The Brooklyn-based duo Rubblebucket produces dancy indie pop that combines influences from across the musical world. Blending rock, pop, ska, electronic, reggae, and international, Rubblebucket does not shy away from exploring how sound and color combine to create a memorable listening experience. The music of Rubblebucket is comparable to groups like Passion Pit and Vampire Weekend. Their latest album, "If U C My Enemies," was released in 2017. Joining Rubblebucket is the indie rock band And The Kids. Where: The Haunt, 702 Willow Ave., Ithaca When: 8 p.m. on Tuesday, Dec. 4 How much: Tickets are $20. Details here. Eliza Neals & The Narcotics Eliza Neals is a blues artist whose voice and live performances are as enchanting as they are outstanding. Neals, a critically acclaimed singer, is also a notable pianist, arranger, and bandleader. Throughout a celebrated career, Neals' most recent award was "Blues Artist of the Year" at the 2018 Detroit Black Music Awards. Backed by a talented group of musicians with The Narcotics, Eliza Neals will bring you to your feet. Where: Funk 'n Waffles Syracuse, 307-313 Clinton St., Syracuse When: 8 p.m. on Wednesday, Dec. 5 How much: Tickets start at $7. Details here. Taj Weekes & Adowa Humanitarian, Rastafarian, and reggae artist Taj Weekes is a dynamic singer and songwriter who utilizes his creativity and voice to help build a better world. His songs offer compassionate idealism while reflecting upon real world issues with sophistication and skill. Taj Weekes also has an official role with the United Nations as a "UNICEF Champion for Children." Adowa is the musical group that accompanies Taj Weekes and they masterfully showcase their talents as instrumentalists. Together, Taj Weekes & Adowa create a powerful musical force. Where: The Haunt, 702 Willow Ave., Ithaca When: 9 p.m. on Wednesday, Dec. 5 How much: Tickets are $5. Details here. Moksi Dutch duo Samir and Diego, also known as Moksi, bring the party with their brand of bass-heavy electronic music. Their first EP, "Brace Yourself," was released in 2015, giving them a launching pad to grow an international fanbase. Moksi continues to produce danceable electronic tracks, showing no signs of slowing down as they sweep up fans in their musical journey. Where: The Westcott Theater, 524 Westcott St., Syracuse When: 8:30 p.m. on Saturday, Dec. 8 How much: Tickets are $15. Details here. Granny 4 Barrel Granny 4 Barrel is a steampunk-ish neo-Victorian shock rock group with a desire to buck metal conventions while promoting freedom of self-expression. Adopting the persona of a rocking matriarch and her sinister backing band, the group hopes to get you off your seat and onto your feet with an optimistic "anything is possible" mindset. Granny 4 Barrel will be joined by metal band Killaton and funk band Neglected Foot. Where: The Lost Horizon, 5863 Thompson Road, Syracuse When: 9 p.m. on Saturday, Dec. 8 How much: Tickets start at $10. Details here. Mike Greenlar Lots of shows across Upstate NY this week. Dave Matthews Band plays the Times Union Center in Albany on Dec. 5. Jerry Seinfeld appears at the Stanley Theater in Utica on Dec. 6. Also on Dec. 6, Brett Young and Tyler Rich play the Palace Theater in Albany.
6075.txt.next_sentence_generated: His most recent EP was the celebrated Black & Green Music Awards of 2018

6135.txt.context_sentence: Conveniently timed to be published just 20 days before Christmas, the section gave department stores and television companies a chance to showcase their wares to potential consumers.
6135.txt.next_sentence_true: The section also gave a chance for local reporters to give predictions about the future of the medium and a to herald Syracuse as a future "Capital of Television." Copyright 2004 Heritage Microfilm Glossary of terms Television was so new to Syracuse that the section got underway with a glossary of the most basic terms about the new technology to inform potential customers.
6135.txt.full: On Dec. 1, 1948, from the WHEN studios, Syracuse's first television program went on the air. Beginning at 8:30 p.m., the show opened with harpist Melville Clark smiling nervously into a huge camera, while blinding lights burned overhead. Clark opened the two-hour program talking about his recent trip to England, where he had visited Princess Elizabeth. Then he played "Home on the Range" and "Drink to Me Only with Thine Eyes" on his harp. The telecast concluded with a travelogue program, "Wings in Viking Land," a newscast and some short films. Despite announcer William Bohen asking the television audience for their patience, the telecast was considered a complete success. Telephone calls praised the studio about the wonderful reception. Onondaga Historical Association 'A stirring story of achievement' The WHEN studio, on Court Street and Oswego Boulevard, had been readied for broadcasting after only 16 days, a mark the Herald-American called a "stirring story of achievement" and a "historic event." In an editorial on Dec. 5, 1948, the newspaper said the city of Syracuse "welcomes the miracle of television" and called the moment a "fitting climax to the city's centennial year." The editors of the paper saw the introduction of television as a turning point in the average Syracusan's life "No one can forecast what will the impact of television be on our modern life," the editorial said. "But there can be no doubt that this new means of entertainment and instruction will exert a powerful influence and will become an indispensable part of modern living." Copyright 2004 Heritage Microfilm WHEN is on the air In the same newspaper, the Herald-American published a special "video section" giving its readers a chance to read up on the new technology. Conveniently timed to be published just 20 days before Christmas, the section gave department stores and television companies a chance to showcase their wares to potential consumers. The section also gave a chance for local reporters to give predictions about the future of the medium and a to herald Syracuse as a future "Capital of Television." Copyright 2004 Heritage Microfilm Glossary of terms Television was so new to Syracuse that the section got underway with a glossary of the most basic terms about the new technology to inform potential customers. Examples: TELEVISION: The simultaneous transmission of sight and sound by radio from one point to another. VIDEO: The visual part of a television program that is, what you see on the screen of your receiving set. TELECAST: A television program, as distinguished from a "broadcast," which is applied to standard radio programs. SCREEN: The frame or panel of you set on which you view the visual portion of the telecast. COAXIAL CABLE: A highly complicated cable for transmission of television programs. Associated Press Bringing the family back together again The cover page also introduced readers to the most important people in the local television industry. But it was not news reporters or entertainers that merited any publicity, but instead the engineers and managers who had worked tirelessly to get the first telecast beamed into local homes. (As if to further its praise of the accomplishment, the Herald-American called WHEN's first telecast "one of the most amazing feats since Henry Kaiser built his Victory ship in less than a week.") The most important person in the first days of Syracuse television was Capt. William Eddy, director of television for Meredith Engineering Corp., president of Television Associates managing WHEN. He was a graduate of the Naval Academy and had served in the submarine service until 1934, when he entered the new television industry. He saw great things for TV's future and the role it would have on the American family, echoing the sentiment of sociologists who predicted that TV would replace "entertainment outside of the home." "TV," Eddy said, "may very well change the picture of American life. I think television will bring the family of this generation closer together, a tighter more congenial unit. I can see the television receiver where the fireplace used to be, bringing the family back together again." Copyright 2004 Heritage Microfilm 'Feeling out procedure' What kind of entertainment was WHEN expecting to air? General Manager Paul Adanti asked that WHEN's audience be patient and said that the studio would be going be going through a "feeling out procedure." But he expected to have more live entertainment shot from the studio, like Melville Clark had been on opening night. "Did anyone know a juggler," he asked. Motion pictures were "handy" choices, both time-consuming and entertaining. After the last of the "bugs" were fixed Syracuse could expect the station's "mobile unit" to be set up, beaming programs from around the city. Eventually this could lead to high school and college sports being televised, if the sport did not "cover too much arena territory." Educational features and quiz shows were planned, and station managers were looking for ways to attract young viewers. "Kids, always happy to see something new - and a potent medium for cereal and bread advertisers - are among the greatest exponents of TV." A child's puppet show was currently the highest rated program in New York City and WHEN executives were looking to create their own Syracuse version.
6135.txt.next_sentence_generated: But that kind of influence was also expected as new technology got underway; with most customers talking about future predictions for Television & Microfilm soi&quot <b>Glossary basic terms

I can see the television receiver where the fireplace used to be, bringing the family back together again." Copyright 2004 Heritage Microfilm 'Feeling out procedure' What kind of entertainment was WHEN expecting to air? General Manager Paul Adanti asked that WHEN's audience be patient and said that the studio would be going be going through a "feeling out procedure." But he expected to have more live entertainment shot from the studio, like Melville Clark had been on opening night. "Did anyone know a juggler," he asked. Motion pictures were "handy" choices, both time-consuming and entertaining. After the last of the "bugs" were fixed Syracuse could expect the station's "mobile unit" to be set up, beaming programs from around the city. Eventually this could lead to high school and college sports being televised, if the sport did not "cover too much arena territory." Educational features and quiz shows were planned, and station managers were looking for ways to attract young viewers. "Kids, always happy to see something new - and a potent medium for cereal and bread advertisers - are among the greatest exponents of TV." A child's puppet show was currently the highest rated program in New York City and WHEN executives were looking to create their own Syracuse version. There was even talk of bringing more interactivity between people's living rooms and what they were watching on screen, much like today's reality shows. In one scenario, viewers could watch the Miss America pageant and vote for the winners via letter or wire. (How long it would take to announce the winner was not mentioned.) Copyright 2004 Heritage Microfilm TV will help homemakers In the 1940s gender roles were well-defined. Men were most often the breadwinners and their wives stayed home and raised the children. Arlene LaRue, the Herald's women's editor, wrote an article about what television coming to Syracuse meant for area housewives. "Armchair shopping. Homemaking demonstrations. Sewing hints. Beauty shortcuts. Fashion shows. These and many more modern miracles loom on the horizon for the busy homemaker with the advent of television," LaRue wrote. "It's pleasant to think," she continued, "of how television will make like easier for women." LaRue pictured cooking programs showing hints and techniques right on the screen. ("Imagine watching how to knead dough so the bread will rise!") She predicted television programs originating from grocery stores, showcasing the best each store had to offer. A woman could finish her grocery list while watching television. Fashion editors would take women on tours of department stores through the television screen and show off the latest fashions. Women who sewed at home could see the latest patterns and trends. (In a later article in the section a writer thought men too would enjoy watching these fashion segments: "Father will see how to tie his tie. He will be able to enjoy fashion shows, so he can expound his opinions on women's clothes.") Post-Standard file photo Syracuse: Capital of Television The arrival of television meant more to Syracuse than just another form of entertainment. With the opening of the new General Electric plant at Electronics Park, Syracuse, the Herald-American said, is "destined to become the television capital of the world." Out of the more than 7,100 employees at the GE plant, about 3,000 were engaged in TV work in the numerous laboratories and along the production lines in the big transmitter and receiver buildings. About 5,000 television sets a week were produced at the local plant, proudly carrying the G.E. Syracuse label to cities all over the eastern part of the United States. Meanwhile station transmitters and other equipment for new stations in Los Angeles, Miami, Houston, San Francisco and Miami were being manufactured here. Electronics Park was becoming "a mecca" for thousands of people inside the new industry. Dealers and distributors made visits to get first-hand information on production and new designs. Even rival manufacturers sent representatives to discuss mutual problems and look over the new facilities. Copyright 2004 Heritage Microfilm Emerson's Complete Instrument As the Christmas season got started, Central New Yorkers interested in a new television for the holidays had plenty of choices. General Electric, Emerson, Motorola, Philco and RCA Victor were just some of the brands which advertised in the special video section. Emerson's Model 585, selling at Edwards Department Store for $495, was one of the more luxurious sets on the market. Promising "Image Perfection" on a big 52-square-inch screen, giving viewers superb day and night reception of all programs. It was billed as an "amazing COMPLETE instrument." Besides the TV screen, it featured a super-powered FM and AM Phonoradio with automatic record changer, all built inside a luxurious console. Copyright 2004 Heritage Microfilm GE's Daylight Television General Electric bill itself as "First in Radio - now Leader in Television." GE's innovation was called "Daylight Television,"which the company claimed gave "the brightest, clearest picture under the sun." "Never until General Electric achieved this revolutionary new picture-brightness could you fully enjoy the clear, definite realism television should bring you!" A table model, with a ten-inch direct view tube, cost $325 at Chappell's, while the fancier console version with AM/FM radio and automatic photograph cost $395.95. Copyright 2004 Heritage Microfilm RCA: First in Television RCA Victor proclaimed itself to be the world leader in radio and was now "1st in television." Its line of televisions for 1949 included a bevy of brand-new features, none of which probably makes any sense today. The new features included: the RCA Victor Multi-Channel Station Selector, Automatic Gain Control, Four Stage I-F Amplifier, Four Tuned Circuits, Shielded Television Chassis, and Fine-Tuning Control, as well as, "many others too numerous to mention." RCA models included the "Bystander" for $325 and the "Sightseer" which cost $395 but came with its own matching television table. "The Harrison" was RCA's most luxurious model. Called "one beautifully designed piece of furniture," the unit promised "Big and Bright" television pictures, the listening pleasure of radio programs," and a "fine automatic record changer." The "Golden Throat" tone system, reproduced television sound, recorded music and radio broadcasts with unbelievable fullness and clarity. Enclosed in a hand-rubbed cabinet, the set starts at $550. Copyright 2004 Heritage Microfilm Motorola: Television's Greatest Value Motorola's VT71 was one of the better bargains during the 1948 Christmas season. The unit promised clear-as-crystal television action, with smooth-as-silk FM sound, in a handsome furniture-styled cabinet, "hand-rubbed to give extra beauty to your living room." Available in walnut, mahogany or blonde wood, the TV weighed just 26 pounds, easy enough to carry from room to room. "The simplified controls make it easy to operate...its budget-low price makes it easy to own."

Celebrity deaths 2018: Famous people who died this year (photos) The list of celebrity deaths in 2018 is just as devastating as it has been the past few years. Do "celebrity deaths come in threes?" Famous people who died in 2017 include Tom Petty, Hugh Hefner, Chris Cornell and Mary Tyler Moore; 2016 saw the loss of Prince, Alan Rickman, Carrie Fisher, Muhammad Ali and David Bowie. Stars we lost this year include President George H.W. Bush, "Queen of Soul" Aretha Franklin, Marvel Comics legend Stan Lee, actor Burt Reynolds, "Superman" actress Margot Kidder, superstar DJ-producer Avicii, Sen. John McCain, celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain, designer Kate Spade, theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking, actress-director Penny Marshall, CNY comedian Barry Crimmins, The Cranberries singer Dolores O'Riordan and rappers Mac Miller, Craig Mack and XXXTentacion. 974.txt.full: Michael Greenlar | mgreenlar@syracuse.com Aretha Franklin sings on the main stage at the 25th annual Syracuse M&T Jazz Fest at OCC in 2007. Celebrity deaths 2018: Famous people who died this year (photos) The list of celebrity deaths in 2018 is just as devastating as it has been the past few years. Do "celebrity deaths come in threes?" Famous people who died in 2017 include Tom Petty, Hugh Hefner, Chris Cornell and Mary Tyler Moore; 2016 saw the loss of Prince, Alan Rickman, Carrie Fisher, Muhammad Ali and David Bowie. Stars we lost this year include President George H.W. Bush, "Queen of Soul" Aretha Franklin, Marvel Comics legend Stan Lee, actor Burt Reynolds, "Superman" actress Margot Kidder, superstar DJ-producer Avicii, Sen. John McCain, celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain, designer Kate Spade, theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking, actress-director Penny Marshall, CNY comedian Barry Crimmins, The Cranberries singer Dolores O'Riordan and rappers Mac Miller, Craig Mack and XXXTentacion.
